content.description: Connect the cracks up the scarred wall past one bolt. Moving left can be tricky as the grooves trend right. Take care placing 1 more cam (#2) after the bolt, as it is good but can be finnicky. This is just fun. Climb it. Stay on your feet and enjoy.
content.protection: I use a #1 #2 and #3 camalot and a few draws.
content.location: On the left side of the crag look for the claw-mark like cracks. That's the jam.

content.description: What a feature! you can't miss the wide off-width flake that marks the upper half of the route. Every time you walk by and don't climb this route you are taking a year off of a baby seal's life. Pad up the friction slab past 2 bolts (optional gear between) and stand beneath the flake of the gods. Place more gear on your way up the crack (I hope you brought your number #6 camalot! Once the #6 is in place rock your way up the flake to the top out. Clip the tree-sling/Biner anchor and take another lap... If you care about seals...
content.location: Toward the right end of the cliff. You can't miss the big with flake on the upper wall.

content.description: This was Torie's first 100% her own, route she put up. It is delicate and technical and every time I climb it I think about how slippery it was soaked in parts on the first ascent. Start on the vertical wall around the right hand corner. Make steep moves over onto the slab and then get dancing! Tictac your way past 4 bolts and onto a 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts and onto a 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Look for the claw Marks in the left slab. This is the route to the right of that. Start just around the corner.

content.description: This is the loose blocky chimney in the corner of the alcove. With a cleaning it might just be fun. In it's present state I Have to say, sadly, don't bother. We climbed it in a fit of excitement when it was soaking wet. Although it was cool in a way, I guess my lead was a bad call even though I pulled through. I couldn't find protection aside from a VERY tipped out #6 cam for the crux exit and the lichen was comically slippery...If my life didn't depend on friction. Sometimes simply surviving isn't enough. Next time I hope I have the presence of mind to wait until it's dry, clean it and make it feel good. You think I will? Or will I get up to my old tricks again?
content.location: The chimney in the corner of the alcove.

content.description: A pretty little cliff by the stream. Best identified by the claw marks in the slab on the left end of the crag . Easily seen from the main trail. A variety of climbs despite not having too many. It is a wonderfully quiet place and in the spring the stream it is named for babbles all day.
